sentence1: And should you ask the reason, a farmer will tell you, "The lightning did that."
sentence2: I will tell you what the sparrow told me, and the sparrow heard it from an aged willow which stood--and still stands for that matter--close to the field of buckwheat.

sentence1: I will tell you what the sparrow told me, and the sparrow heard it from an aged willow which stood--and still stands for that matter--close to the field of buckwheat.
sentence2: "I am quite as rich as the oats," it said;

sentence1: "I am quite as rich as the oats," it said;
sentence2: Old willow, do you know anything more beautiful than we?"

sentence1: Old willow, do you know anything more beautiful than we?"
sentence2: The willow nodded his head, as much as to say, "Indeed I do!"

sentence1: The willow nodded his head, as much as to say, "Indeed I do!"
sentence2: "Bow your heads, as we do," called the flowers.

sentence1: "Bow your heads, as we do," called the flowers.
sentence2: "There is no need for me to do that," answered the buckwheat.

sentence1: "There is no need for me to do that," answered the buckwheat.
sentence2: "Bow your head as we do," said the grain.

sentence1: "Bow your head as we do," said the grain.
sentence2: "The angel of storms comes flying hither.

sentence1: "The angel of storms comes flying hither.
sentence2: He has wings that reach from the clouds to the earth;

sentence1: He has wings that reach from the clouds to the earth;
sentence2: he will smite you before you have time to beg for mercy."

sentence1: he will smite you before you have time to beg for mercy."
sentence2: "But I do not choose to bow down," said the buckwheat.

sentence1: "But I do not choose to bow down," said the buckwheat.
sentence2: "Close your flowers and fold your leaves," said the old willow.

sentence1: "Close your flowers and fold your leaves," said the old willow.
sentence2: Even human beings dare not do that, for in the midst of the lightning one may look straight into God's heaven.

sentence1: Even human beings dare not do that, for in the midst of the lightning one may look straight into God's heaven.
sentence2: The sight strikes human beings blind, so dazzling is it.

sentence1: The sight strikes human beings blind, so dazzling is it.
sentence2: If there is a chance, I shall look right into God's heaven."

sentence1: If there is a chance, I shall look right into God's heaven."
sentence2: The old willow waved his branches to and fro in the wind, and large drops of water fell from his green leaves, as if he were shedding tears.

sentence1: The old willow waved his branches to and fro in the wind, and large drops of water fell from his green leaves, as if he were shedding tears.
sentence2: The sparrows asked: "Why are you weeping when all around seems blest?

sentence1: The sparrows asked: "Why are you weeping when all around seems blest?
sentence2: Do you not smell the sweet perfume of flowers and bushes?

sentence1: Do you not smell the sweet perfume of flowers and bushes?
sentence2: Why do you weep, old tree?"

sentence1: Why do you weep, old tree?"
sentence2: Then the willow told them of the buckwheat's stubborn pride and of the punishment which followed.

sentence1: Then the willow told them of the buckwheat's stubborn pride and of the punishment which followed.
sentence2: I, who tell this tale, heard it from the sparrows.

sentence1: I, who tell this tale, heard it from the sparrows.
sentence2: They told it to me one evening when I had asked them for a story.
